subject: Re: [junit] Re: How to test private methods in a class.
msgSnippet: ... With a lot of care this would work in some situations. If you made the classes the that implemented the interfaces non-public, and provided access to them
messageBody:
J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> private is not the only way, nor necessarily the best way, to hide
> implementation details. I use interfaces instead.

With a lot of care this would work in some situations. If you made the
classes the that implemented the interfaces non-public, and provided
access to them through some sort of factory, it might work. It's more
complex but doable. You need to be careful not to expose the
implementation classes or people will use them in preference to the
interfaces, either deliberately or out of carelessness. If they write
their own implementations then you're virtually guaranteed they'll code
to the class rather than the interface. I see this all the time.

The real problem though is that Java is not designed to work this way.
Interfaces are not meant to replace classes. In particular, the lack of
method preconditions and postconditions means that you can no longer
make any promises about what a given method accepts or returns beyond
the simple return type. The reason we have access protection as a
language feature is because we cannot rely on programmer convention to
enforce rules. Using interfaces instead of classes reduces us to using
programmer convention to enforce constraints that should be enforced in
code. There are languages where preconditions and postconditions are
part of the method signature, and in these languages, using interfaces
instead of classes is feasible. However, Java is not such a language. :-(
